subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
author: Rj
full_text:
--0-1315638298-1241993580=:62585
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

They are not necessarily the same bytes, but I was proposing a quick check =
just to see if the files were in the same ballpark.=A0 Look at it the other=
 way: if the number of bytes were DIFFERENT, than you'd know the files HAD =
changed, and you could stop testing.=A0 But if the number of bytes are the =
same, it tends to indicate the files are likely the same, but you still nee=
d a low level file comparison to be sure.

My method is to compare the file=
s using the CMP command in unix.=A0 There are many programs to compare file=
s, but you have to be careful not to use one that does a line-by-line compa=
re (or a comparison meant for text files), since text files can be differen=
t at a low level, but look essential the same in an editor (because of the =
way spaces and tabs and new lines work between editors and platforms).

But=
 anyway, the way to compare is with a program that can compare binary files=
, not text files.

  =
  
            
            


      
      


So if the number of bytes ma=
tch then they 
are the same bytes? See where my confusion comes in?
=A0
How=
 does one do a bit-level comparison? Is 
there a program that does that, or=
 is there some way of comparison by looking at 
the file's properties?
=A0
=

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: 
  Rj 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .=
com 
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 3:35 PM
  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File upl=
oading 
  rules-ATTENTION JON
  

  
  
  
    
    
      A file's content=
, it's integrity, is simply the bytes 
        (and their bits) in the file=
.=A0 If the file's content integrity is 
        changed, that is, by defin=
ition, changing the bytes.=A0 If the bytes 
        in there are not change=
d, then that integrity has not changed.

It 
        is possible to mess wi=
th other things about a file (like its name, its 
        suffix, or its ow=
nership) but this does not effect the contents, and so 
        would not a=
ffect that integrity, or the sound of the file (assuming you 
        could=
 read it at all after changing the ownership, or the suffix, 
        etc).=


When you do your tests, if you cannot do a bit level 
        comparison,=
 I would recommend at least checking the file sizes.=A0 If 
        they ar=
e identical, there is a very high probability that the content 
        has=
 not changed.

         =
   
            
            
              
              
               =
 Yes you can tell loss of quality by a bit-level 
                  compari=
son.=A0 An audio file is just a file of bytes, that 
                  is l=
ater interpreted by an audio player.=A0 Two files with 
                  t=
he exact same contents, whether they are audio or image or a 
             =
     dababase or an exe, are indistinguishable from each 
                 =
 other.=A0 That is, if I copied the contents of one to a new 
             =
     file, and the contents of the other to a new file, and asked 
        =
          you which file each came from, there would be no way to 
        =
          tell.=A0 Even the audio player could not tell.=A0 The 
          =
        data is identical, and so the sound (or the picture, etc) 
        =
          would be identical.

Yes I did listen to the results, 
          =
        but that is not the best test (they sounded identical, but 
       =
           that is a subjective opinion).=A0 The real test is compring 
   =
               the contents.=A0 Identical contents means indentical data, 
=
                  means identical audio.

It is probably possible to set 
 =
                 up an email compression scheme that does do lossy audio 
 =
                 compression.=A0 My tests show my setup does not.=A0 If 
  =
                you'd like me to help test your setup, we can do that too. =

                  From what I see, lossy compression from an attachment wo=
uld be 
                  very unusual.

cking the sizes when they arrived at

ce they came back to MSN, I then did a

     =
                         
                              
                  =
            
                              For 
                           =
   executables, you may be right. However, for wav 
                       =
       files, the compression during email is not loss 
                   =
           less. 
                              =A0
                       =
       I used to 
                              think as you do, in that th=
e emailed 
                              attachment=A0of a wav file would n=
ot loose 
                              anything. After a lengthy discourse=
 with another 
                              member here, I learned that I =
was wrong. The 
                              reason why=A0I did not realiz=
e it in the first 
                              place is that when I would=
 email a wav file, I 
                              would intentionally kee=
p it in very small 
                              segments, to keep file si=
ze down. This was just 
                              for ease of transfer.=
 But because of this, I had 
                              not experienced =
any noticeable loss.
                              =A0
                    =
          Now it may be 
                              in some cases, depen=
ding on the servers or what 
                              have you that th=
e file goes through, that the loss 
                              may be le=
ss or more. But once the attachment is 
                              downl=
oaded,=A0the=A0quality=A0has been 
                              found to b=
e less then the original 
                              wav.
              =
                =A0
                              Again though 
           =
                   you can only really tell when the=A0wav file is 
       =
                       large.
                              =A0
           =
                   ----- Original Message ----- 
                          =
    From: 
                                Rj 
                            =
    
                                To: 
                                E=
VP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                                Sent: 
           =
                     Sunday, May 10, 2009 1:36 PM
                         =
       Subject: 
                                Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploadi=
ng rules
                                

                                =

                                
                                
        =
                        
                                
                 =
               The kind of compression that 
                              =
  occurs during an email attachment is "lossless": 
                       =
         it compress the file cleverly without losing 
                    =
            information.=A0 For example, if I had a 
                      =
          program in some .exe files, and I sent it over 
                 =
               email, it could compress it.=A0 But if it 
                 =
               lost even one bit, the resulting exe file would 
           =
                     not execute again after it was uncompressed on 
      =
                          the other side.

This kind of compression 
      =
                          does things like looking for common patterns in 
=
                                the file, and replacing them with a token.=
=A0 
                                A rough example would be if it found "=
Howdy 
                                Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it cou=
ld replace 
                                all the occurances with say $HN=
1.=A0 And also 
                                write a little dictionary i=
n there someplace 
                                that says "$HN1=3DHowdy =
Neighbor".

When the 
                                file gets to its dest=
ination it can be 
                                uncompressed, and all oc=
curences of $HN1 are 
                                replaced with "Howdy =
Neighbor".=A0 So it was 
                                compressed (instea=
d of 14 characters each, it 
                                only needed 4,=
 plus the dictionary), but lost no 
                                data.

=
Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. 
                                are not l=
ossless.=A0 Depending on the level 
                                of comp=
ression, some level of data is lost, and 
                                s=
o cannot be recovered or reconstructed 
                                lat=
er.

Rick

     =
                           Another 
                                thing:
=
                                =A0
                                I recen=
tly 
                                found this out. When you email a file,=
 if it is 
                                not saved as a compressed format=
, the email 
                                filtering process will actuall=
y compress the 
                                file automatically.
       =
                         =A0
                                So even if 
  =
                              you have attached a wav. file, it will loose =

                                resolution over the email process. It will=
 not 
                                sound exactly the same as the origina=
l wav. 
                                file. How much it differs depends o=
n the size of 
                                the file you are attaching. =
If it is a 
                                very=A0large file, it will soun=
d much 
                                different.
                        =
        =A0
                                The only 
                     =
           exception to this is if the wav. file is small 
                =
                enough that the filtering process will ignore 
            =
                    it. It has to be pretty small though, like under 
     =
                           1=A0MB (I am not exactly sure of the 
          =
                      threshold).
                                =A0
     =
                           The best way 
                                to=
 share files over the internet=A0if you 
                                wa=
nt them as close to the original as possible 
                             =
   is to upload them directly to a 
                                website=
.
                                =A0
                                
    =
                            ----- 
                                Original=
 Message ----- 
                                From: 
                    =
            Rj 
                                
                          =
      To: 
                                EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
      =
                          Sent: 
                                Sunday, Ma=
y 10, 2009 10:54 AM
                                Subject: 
             =
                   Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                     =
           

                                
                             =
   
                                
                                
     =
                           
                                
Pixelization d=
oesn't clean-up 
                                the data: it replaces it.=
=A0 Imagine taking a 
                                picture of a field of=
 flowers, and beginning to 
                                add levels or p=
ixelization to the picture.=A0 
                                Soon, you w=
ould not be able to tell there were 
                                flower=
s there at all.=A0 You would see a lot 
                                of =
colored blocks.

Or in the other 
                                direction=
, imagine you are looking at a 
                                competely r=
andomize bunch of pixes on your 
                                screen: a =
complete screen of truely random 
                                static sn=
ow.=A0 Pixelizing this, after a 
                                while, you=
 would again start to see colored 
                                blocks.
=

What's happening is that it is 
                                processing=
 an area of the image, taking (for 
                                instanc=
e) the average value of that entire area, 
                                =
and replacing all the blocks in that area with 
                           =
     the average.=A0 In video processing, this 
                           =
     would result in a field of multi-colored flowers 
                    =
            being replaced by, for instance, a big 
                       =
         greyish-bluish block, with no resemblance to 
                    =
            flowers.=A0 In the noise example, it maybe 
                   =
             replace all the random pixels with another big 
              =
                  greyish-bluish block.=A0 If you did not know 
           =
                     beforehand what the original picture was, you 
       =
                         couldn't tell whether your pixelized image was 
  =
                              really a field of flowers, a chevy, the sky w=
ith 
                                clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.

=
It 
                                works the same with the sound files.=A0=
 
                                Taking something as complex as speech, an=
d 
                                replacing frequencies with their average=
s, loses 
                                the speech the farther you go, un=
til you head 
                                strange fluctuating square wa=
ves.=A0 Doing 
                                the same to random static wi=
ll eventually 
                                produce the same thing.=A0 A=
nd random 
                                fluctuating square waves can sou=
nd a bit like 
                                speech - or at least, you co=
uld have fun sharing 
                                with each other what =
you thing they 'sound 
                                like'.

                            =
    
                                
                                
    =
                            
                                
             =
                   Be a bit careful of formats like 
                      =
          mp3 if you are doing a detailed analysis of the 
                =
                sounds though.=A0=A0 While some formats 
                  =
              (like wav) can store the audio very close to the 
           =
                     way it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress 
      =
                          the file, and in so doing lose some of the sonic =

                                details.=A0 This may not be a big deal in =

                                music, where the audio is fairly clear to =
begin 
                                with.=A0 But with sound sources with=
 a lot of 
                                noise (like evps), this can not =
only obscure any 
                                real sounds, but pixelize=
 non-sounds (like white 
                                noise) and make th=
em start to sound like 
                                speech.

So mp3 mig=
ht be good for sharing 
                                the data, once you'=
ve already formed an opinion 
                                based on an a=
nalysis of the wav file.=A0 But 
                                mp3 is not=
 good as a medium for analysis.=A0 
                                It can =
lead to many false positives and 
                                misinterp=
retations.

top" style=3D"font: inherit;">They are not necessarily the same bytes, but =
I was proposing a quick check just to see if the files were in the same bal=
lpark.  Look at it the other way: if the number of bytes were DIFFEREN=
T, than you'd know the files HAD changed, and you could stop testing. =
 But if the number of bytes are the same, it tends to indicate the files ar=
e likely the same, but you still need a low level file comparison to be sur=
e.<br><br>My method is to compare the files using the CMP command in unix.&=
nbsp; There are many programs to compare files, but you have to be careful =
not to use one that does a line-by-line compare (or a comparison meant for =
text files), since text files can be different at a low level, but look ess=
ential the same in an editor (because of the way spaces and tabs and new li=
nes work between editors and platforms).<br><br>But anyway, the way to comp=
are
 is with a program that can compare binary files, not text files.<br><b=
r><br>--- On <b>Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <i><april@abercrombiegho=

      <td valign=
=3D"top">A file's content, it's integrity, is simply the bytes 
        (an=
d their bits) in the file.  If the file's content integrity is 
      =
  changed, that is, by definition, changing the bytes.  If the bytes 
=
        in there are not changed, then that integrity has not changed.<br><=
br>It 
        is possible to mess with other things about a file (like its=
 name, its 
        suffix, or its ownership) but this does not effect the =
contents, and so 
        would not affect that integrity, or the sound of =
the file (assuming you 
        could read it at all after changing the own=
ership, or the suffix, 
        etc).<br><br>When you do your tests, if you=
 cannot do a bit level 
        comparison, I would recommend at least chec=
king the file sizes.  If 
        they are identical, there is a very =
high probability that the content 
        has not changed.<br><br><br><br>=

                <td valign=3D"t=
op">Yes you can tell loss of quality by a bit-level 
                  comp=
arison.  An audio file is just a file of bytes, that 
                =
  is later interpreted by an audio player.  Two files with 
          =
        the exact same contents, whether they are audio or image or a 
    =
              dababase or an exe, are indistinguishable from each 
        =
          other.  That is, if I copied the contents of one to a new 
 =
                 file, and the contents of the other to a new file, and ask=
ed 
                  you which file each came from, there would be no way =
to 
                  tell.  Even the audio player could not tell.&nbs=
p; The 
                  data is identical, and so the sound (or the pictu=
re, etc) 
                  would be identical.<br><br>Yes I did listen to =
the results, 
                  but that is not the best test (they sounded=
 identical, but 
                  that is a subjective opinion).  The=
 real test is compring 
                  the contents.  Identical con=
tents means indentical data, 
                  means identical audio.<br><=
br>It is probably possible to set 
                  up an email compressio=
n scheme that does do lossy audio 
                  compression.  My =
tests show my setup does not.  If 
                  you'd like me to =
help test your setup, we can do that too. 
                  From what I se=
e, lossy compression from an attachment would be 
                  very un=
usual.<br><br><br>--- On <b>Sun, 5/10/09, April 
                  Abercrom=
bie <i><april@abercrombiegh ostresearch.

                          <td valign=3D"top">I can't vouch f=

nd once turning it off.   I

                            was=

                                <td valign=3D"top">The kind=
 of compression that 
                                occurs during an emai=
l attachment is "lossless": 
                                it compress th=
e file cleverly without losing 
                                information=
.  For example, if I had a 
                                program in=
 some .exe files, and I sent it over 
                                email=
, it could compress it.  But if it 
                                lo=
st even one bit, the resulting exe file would 
                            =
    not execute again after it was uncompressed on 
                       =
         the other side.<br><br>This kind of compression 
                 =
               does things like looking for common patterns in 
           =
                     the file, and replacing them with a token.  
    =
                            A rough example would be if it found "Howdy 
  =
                              Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it could replac=
e 
                                all the occurances with say $HN1.  =
And also 
                                write a little dictionary in ther=
e someplace 
                                that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neighb=
or".<br><br>When the 
                                file gets to its dest=
ination it can be 
                                uncompressed, and all oc=
curences of $HN1 are 
                                replaced with "Howdy =
Neighbor".  So it was 
                                compressed (ins=
tead of 14 characters each, it 
                                only needed=
 4, plus the dictionary), but lost no 
                                data=
.<br><br>Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. 
                                =
are not lossless.  Depending on the level 
                           =
     of compression, some level of data is lost, and 
                     =
           so cannot be recovered or reconstructed 
                       =
         later.<br><br>Rick<br><br><br><br>--- On <b>Sun, 
                =
                5/10/09, April Abercrombie 
                               =
 <i><april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. 
                                c=
om></i></b> wrote:<br>
                                <blockquote style=

       =

                                =
<div><font face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2">I recently 
                     =
           found this out. When you email a file, if it is 
               =
                 not saved as a compressed format, the email 
             =
                   filtering process will actually compress the 
          =
                      file automatically.</font></div>
                    =
            <div><font face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2"></font> </div>
 =
                               <div><font face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2">So=
 even if 
                                you have attached a wav. file, it=
 will loose 
                                resolution over the email proc=
ess. It will not 
                                sound exactly the same as=
 the original wav. 
                                file. How much it diffe=
rs depends on the size of 
                                the file you are=
 attaching. If it is a 
                                very large fil=
e, it will sound much 
                                different.</font></d=
iv>
                                <div><font face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"=
2"></font> </div>
                                <div><font face=3D"M=
yriad Pro" size=3D"2">The only 
                                exception t=
o this is if the wav. file is small 
                                enough=
 that the filtering process will ignore 
                                it=
. It has to be pretty small though, like under 
                           =
     1 MB (I am not exactly sure of the 
                             =
   threshold).</font></div>
                                <div><font face=
=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2"></font> </div>
                            =
    <div><font face=3D"Myriad Pro" size=3D"2">The best way 
               =
                 to share files over the internet if you 
            =
                    want them as close to the original as possible 
       =
                         is to upload them directly to a 
                 =
               website.</font></div>

     <tr>
                                <td valign=3D"top"><br>Pixelizati=
on doesn't clean-up 
                                the data: it replaces =
it.  Imagine taking a 
                                picture of a fi=
eld of flowers, and beginning to 
                                add level=
s or pixelization to the picture.  
                                So=
on, you would not be able to tell there were 
                             =
   flowers there at all.  You would see a lot 
                       =
         of colored blocks.<br><br>Or in the other 
                       =
         direction, imagine you are looking at a 
                         =
       competely randomize bunch of pixes on your 
                        =
        screen: a complete screen of truely random 
                       =
         static snow.  Pixelizing this, after a 
                     =
           while, you would again start to see colored 
                   =
             blocks.<br><br>What's happening is that it is 
               =
                 processing an area of the image, taking (for 
            =
                    instance) the average value of that entire area, 
     =
                           and replacing all the blocks in that area with 
=
                                the average.
